ChatGPT said:

Alright —fresh Debian 13, security-first, and you’d like “certs over keys” where possible. Here’s a tight plan that gets your Git/GitHub stack sane, signed, and repeatable, plus a quick primer on references like in scientific papers (and how to read despite constant interrupts).

1) What “certs over keys” means on Git/GitHub (reality check)

  • Auth to GitHub.com

    • GitHub does not accept client TLS (X.509) certs for HTTPS auth. You’ll use SSH (recommended) or HTTPS with a PAT.

    • SSH certificates (short-lived certs signed by a CA) are supported only for orgs on GitHub Enterprise Cloud; otherwise you use ordinary SSH keys. GitHub Docs+1

  • Commit/tag signing (to show “Verified” on GitHub)

    • You can sign with GPG, SSH, or S/MIME (X.509). If you truly want “certs,” S/MIME is the cert-based option; SSH signing is also first-class and simpler to run day-to-day. GitHub Docs+2GitHub Docs+2

My recommendation (secure + smooth):

  • Use FIDO2 hardware-backed SSH keys for repo access and for SSH commit signing (clean UX, no external CA needed).

  • If you already have a personal X.509/S/MIME cert from a PKI you trust, you can enable S/MIME commit signing too—but it’s more to maintain. developers.yubico.comhttps://www.hifis.net

2) Install & base config (Debian 13 “Trixie”)

bash
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y git openssh-client gnupg2 gpgsm # gpgsm for S/MIME
# Optional hardware helpers:
sudo apt install -y scdaemon yubikey-manager yubikey-agent

Set your global identity and sane defaults:

bash
git config --global user.name  "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.org"
git config --global pull.rebase false
git config --global init.defaultBranch main
git config --global core.editor "nano"   # or vim, micro, etc.

3) Auth to GitHub with hardware-backed SSH (preferred)

Generate a FIDO2 SSH key (touch-to-use; works great on YubiKey or similar):

bash
# Creates an Ed25519 key tied to your security key (will prompt for touch)
ssh-keygen -t ed25519-sk -a 100 -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_sk_github -C "you@host (github)"
# Fall back to software key if no FIDO2 token:
# ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -a 100 -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_github -C "you@host (github)"

Add the public key to GitHub → Settings → SSH and GPG keys → New SSH key. GitHub Docs

~/.ssh/config (quality-of-life):

sshconfig
Host github.com
  HostName github.com
  User git
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_sk_github
  IdentitiesOnly yes

4) Show “Verified” on GitHub: pick one (or both)

Option A — SSH commit signing (simple, no extra PKI)

  1. Tell Git to use SSH signing and point it at your signing key (can reuse the same hardware key or create a separate one):

bash
git config --global gpg.format ssh
git config --global user.signingkey ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_sk_github.pub
git config --global commit.gpgsign true

  1. Add that public signing key in GitHub → Settings → SSH and GPG keys (as an SSH key so GitHub can verify signatures). developers.yubico.com

Option B — S/MIME (X.509) commit signing (true “certs” path)

If you have a personal X.509 cert (with the right EKU) installed in your user cert store:

bash
git config --global gpg.format x509
git config --global user.signingkey "your.cert@example.org"   # or a path to .p12/.pem via gpgsm
git config --global commit.gpgsign true

GitHub marks these as Verified when it recognizes the cert chain. (This is standard Git since 2.19; GitHub docs confirm S/MIME support.) GitHub Docshttps://www.hifis.net

Note: If you really want SSH certificates (short-lived client certs) to auth to repos, your org must enable an SSH CA on GitHub Enterprise Cloud. For personal accounts or normal orgs on GitHub.com, use regular SSH keys. GitHub Docs

5) Bootstrap “modular everything” script (starter)

This gives you a single, re-runnable setup you can keep in your dotfiles repo. Save as ~/bootstrap/git-secure.sh:

bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

NAME="${1:-"Your Name"}"
EMAIL="${2:-"you@example.org"}"
SIGN_FMT="${3:-"ssh"}"       # ssh | x509
SIGN_KEY="${4:-"$HOME/.ssh/id_ed25519_sk_github.pub"}"  # or email/issuer for x509

# Base identity
git config --global user.name  "$NAME"
git config --global user.email "$EMAIL"
git config --global init.defaultBranch main
git config --global pull.rebase false
git config --global core.autocrlf input
git config --global core.editor "nano"

# SSH quality-of-life
mkdir -p "$HOME/.ssh"
chmod 700 "$HOME/.ssh"
if ! grep -q "Host github.com" "$HOME/.ssh/config" 2>/dev/null; then
  cat >> "$HOME/.ssh/config" <<'EOF'
Host github.com
  HostName github.com
  User git
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_sk_github
  IdentitiesOnly yes
EOF
  chmod 600 "$HOME/.ssh/config"
fi

# Signing
case "$SIGN_FMT" in
  ssh)
    git config --global gpg.format ssh
    git config --global user.signingkey "$SIGN_KEY"
    ;;
  x509)
    git config --global gpg.format x509
    git config --global user.signingkey "$SIGN_KEY"
    ;;
  *)
    echo "Unknown signing format: $SIGN_FMT" ; exit 1 ;;
esac
git config --global commit.gpgsign true

echo "✔ Git secured. Identity: $NAME <$EMAIL>, signing: $SIGN_FMT"

Run it like:

bash
bash ~/bootstrap/git-secure.sh "Christopher Shifflet" "vectortrust@protonmail.com" ssh ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_sk_github.pub
# or for S/MIME:
# bash ~/bootstrap/git-secure.sh "Christopher Shifflet" "vectortrust@protonmail.com" x509 "you@example.org"

bash

7) References “like scientific papers” (and coping with interrupts)

Minimal, robust citation workflow

  • Zotero (+ Better BibTeX) → keeps a .bib that stays in your repo.

  • Pandoc (with CSL style files) → turns your Markdown with [@key] citations into PDF/Docx with a proper bibliography.

  • DOI first: always stash a DOI or arXiv ID in your note so future you can regenerate citations.

Install bits:

bash
sudo apt install -y pandoc texlive-latex-recommended texlive-fonts-recommended
# Zotero: download .deb from zotero.org (or use flatpak), add Better BibTeX plugin.

Markdown example (paper.md):

markdown
We build on the field approach in Turing’s morphogenesis [@turing1952].

# References

Then:

bash
pandoc paper.md --citeproc --bibliography=refs.bib --csl=ieee.csl -o paper.pdf

Staying effective with constant interrupts

  • “Capture, then continue” muscle memory

    • One-keystroke capture to an inbox.md (e.g., Ctrl+Alt+i → append selection/URL to today’s log).

    • Use your commit template’s [Refs] section immediately—paste DOI/URL, then move on.

  • Progress beacons

    • End each session by writing a 1–3 line Next step at the top of the file; you’ll resume in seconds.

  • Atomic notes (Zettelkasten-lite)

    • One idea per short note with an ID (e.g., 2025-08-17-turing-reaction-diffusion.md), then link from your working doc.

  • Structure over perfection

    • Get the scaffold right (folders: /papers/, /notes/, /experiments/), let polish come later. Your commit message template + frequent tiny commits will preserve context you’d otherwise lose.

8) Cloning & pushing (smoke test)

bash
# New repo
mkdir demo && cd demo

echo "# Demo" > README.md
git add .
git commit -S -m "Initial commit (signed)"
# Create repo on GitHub (UI or gh cli), then:
git remote add origin git@github.com:YourUser/demo.git
git push -u origin main

You should see Verified on the commit. (GitHub verifies GPG, SSH, and S/MIME signatures.) GitHub Docs

Totally fair. Let’s shape the firehose to your throughput.

A focus-friendly “info pipeline”

Think in batches and WIP limits. You’ll touch items once, quickly, then deepen only the winners.

0) WIP limits (pick one)

  • Low bandwidth day: INBOX ≤ 10, DOING ≤ 3, PARKING ≤ 10

  • High bandwidth burst: INBOX ≤ 40, DOING ≤ 5, PARKING ≤ 20

1) Intake (10–30 sec per item)

Use a single capture format so you don’t think while triaging.

yaml
# intake.yaml (append per item)
- t: 2025-08-17T16:00-07:00
  src: "doi:10.xxxx/xxxx | url | issue#"
  title: "One-line handle"
  type: paper|issue|task|idea
  est_min: 5|10|20|40
  value: 1-5          # impact
  urgency: 1-5
  note: "why it matters in one sentence"

2) Fast triage (under 1 min/item)

Score priority = value × urgency. Anything < 6 → Archive.
Top 3–5 → DOING today; next 10–20 → PARKING (review later).

3) Deepen in fixed timeboxes

  • 5 min skim → keep or kill.

  • If keep: 15–25 min focus → extract 3 bullets + 1 citation.

  • Done means: a) committed notes, b) next step written, or c) parked with a question.

4) “Progress beacons” (anti-interrupt glue)

At the top of each working file keep:

text
NEXT: (1) ____ (2) ____ (3) ____
BLOCKERS: ____

When interrupted, update those lines, save, git commit -m "wb: note next steps" and step away.

Git/GitHub: make it operational

Repo structure

bash
arl-atft/
  00_inbox/              # raw captures (rotates weekly)
  10_notes/              # zettels, 1 topic each
  20_papers/             # PDFs, bib entries, summaries
  30_models/             # math/code experiments
  90_admin/              # ops, scripts, checklists
refs.bib                 # Better BibTeX export
INTAKE.yaml              # current queue
README.md

Commit hygiene (tiny, frequent)

  • feat: new note/model; ref: literature; wb: work-beacon; doc: docs.

  • Default message template you already set earlier will help; keep commits ≤ 10 changed lines when possible.

Issue template (one screen, no thinking)

.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/intake.yml

yaml
name: Intake
body:
  - type: input
    id: src
    attributes: { label: Source (DOI/URL/handle) }
  - type: input
    id: title
    attributes: { label: Title / Handle }
  - type: dropdown
    id: type
    attributes: { label: Type, options: [paper, issue, task, idea] }
  - type: dropdown
    id: est
    attributes: { label: Est. minutes, options: [5,10,20,40] }
  - type: dropdown
    id: value
    attributes: { label: Value, options: [1,2,3,4,5] }
  - type: dropdown
    id: urgency
    attributes: { label: Urgency, options: [1,2,3,4,5] }
  - type: textarea
    id: note
    attributes: { label: Why it matters (1 sentence) }

Labels + views (one-time setup)

css
gh label create WIP --color 5319e7
gh label create PARK --color bfdadc
gh label create KEEP --color 0e8a16
gh label create KILL --color d73a4a

Use a GitHub Project (table view) with columns INBOX / DOING / PARKING / DONE.

Shell helpers (fast capture)

Add to ~/.zshrc:

bash
cap() {  # cap "title" "src" "type" "est" "value" "urgency" "note"
  printf -- "- t: %s\n  src: \"%s\"\n  title: \"%s\"\n  type: %s\n  est_min: %s\n  value: %s\n  urgency: %s\n  note: \"%s\"\n" \
    "$(date -Is)" "${2:-}" "${1:-}" "${3:-idea}" "${4:-5}" "${5:-1}" "${6:-1}" "${7:-}" >> "$HOME/arl-atft/INTAKE.yaml"
  echo "Captured."
}

wb() {  # wb "next1; next2; next3"
  sed -i "1s|^|NEXT: (${1})\n|" "${2:-README.md}"
  git add -A && git commit -m "wb: ${1}"
}

Now, during a burst you can do:

bash
cap "Turing 1952 revisit" "doi:10.1098/rstb.1952.0012" paper 20 5 4 "reaction-diffusion relevance"

Reading cadence you can trust

  • Daily: 3 items DOING (≈ 60–90 min total).

  • Every 2–3 hours: 10-min INTAKE sweep (batch 5–10 items).

  • End of day: trim PARKING back to the limit; promote tomorrow’s 3.

You said:
what info is needed to add to bibliography entery. how do I easily get this info and store it, is there a cool program of is ther just a over bloated program that costs too much
ChatGPT said:

Good question. Let’s demystify this.

1. What belongs in a bibliography entry?

Depends on the style (APA, IEEE, Chicago, etc.), but the core fields across them all are:

For a journal article:

  • Author(s) (Last, Initials)

  • Year

  • Title of article

  • Journal name (full or abbreviated, style-dependent)

  • Volume (and issue, if present)

  • Page range

  • DOI or URL

For a book:

  • Author(s)/Editor(s)

  • Year

  • Title

  • Edition (if not the first)

  • Publisher

  • Place of publication (sometimes optional now)

  • ISBN

For a web resource:

  • Author or Organization

  • Year (or n.d.)

  • Title of page/document

  • Website name

  • URL

  • Access date (if content can change)

If you use BibTeX/BibLaTeX, these become fields like author, title, journal, year, volume, pages, doi, etc.

2. Easiest way to get this info

You don’t have to type it all by hand:

  • DOI resolver: Paste a DOI at https://doi.org/xxxx → click “Cite” → export BibTeX/APA/etc.

  • Google Scholar: Search → click the quotes icon → grab BibTeX/APA/MLA/Chicago.

  • arXiv: Each paper has a BibTeX entry right on the page.

  • PubMed, ACM, IEEE Xplore: all provide “Export Citation” buttons.

So the trick is: always grab a DOI/URL at intake. Everything else can be auto-pulled later.

3. Programs that make it smooth

Cool + free:

  • Zotero (open source, free):

    • One-click browser plugin saves papers directly.

    • Export whole library as refs.bib for LaTeX/Markdown.

    • Plugins: Better BibTeX → keeps stable citation keys.

  • JabRef (free, BibTeX-first): lightweight desktop app.

  • Obsidian/Zettlr + citation plugin: pulls from Zotero’s .bib and lets you cite inline ([@Turing1952]).

Bloated/expensive (skip unless your institution already pays):

  • EndNote, Mendeley Institutional Edition. They’re overkill and often clunky.

4. Minimal workflow for you (fast + cheap)

  1. Install Zotero + Better BibTeX.

  2. Add the browser extension. When you’re on a paper’s page → one click = full metadata, PDF saved, citation stored.

  3. Zotero auto-updates your refs.bib file in your repo.

  4. In your Markdown/LaTeX: Turing described morphogenesis [@turing1952].

  5. When you run Pandoc/LaTeX → it formats bibliography automatically.

⚡ So the minimum info you need to capture manually at intake is just:
👉 DOI or URL (plus maybe one-line title so you remember what it was).

The rest can be fetched/exported later with Zotero or straight from the DOI resolver.

Do you want me to show you how to set up Zotero so it auto-syncs a refs.bib into your Git repo (so you never have to manually export again)?

You said:
well lets pick a style and make it a LAW ;)
ChatGPT said:

Perfect. If we make it LAW, then every capture, note, and output bends to that style. No waffling. 📚⚖️

1. Candidate Styles

  • APA (7th ed.) → humanities/social sciences, readable, includes DOIs.

  • Chicago (author–date) → history/philosophy heavy, flexible.

  • IEEE → engineering/physics, numeric in-text [42].

  • Nature → similar to IEEE, but more compact.

  • BibTeX default (plain) → generic, easy but ugly.

Given your work (math/physics/metaphysics, GitHub repo, LaTeX/Pandoc integration):

👉 IEEE makes the most sense.

  • It’s what physics/engineering journals expect.

  • Easy to scan in-text ([1], [2], [3]).

  • Pandoc + Zotero + Better BibTeX has IEEE CSL styles prebuilt.

2. The LAW (IEEE edition)

Every reference MUST contain at least:

  • author

  • title

  • journal/book/conference

  • year

  • doi or url

If DOI exists, it’s mandatory.
If no DOI, fallback to stable URL.
If neither → archive copy (Zotero snapshot).

3. Intake Rule

When you grab something:

  1. Capture DOI or URL + one-line title.

  2. Zotero plugin pulls the rest.

  3. Zotero auto-updates refs.bib in repo.

  4. You cite with [@key].

4. Example (IEEE output)

In-text:

Turing’s morphogenesis model first appeared in 1952 [1].

Bibliography:

css
[1] A. M. Turing, "The chemical basis of morphogenesis," 
Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. 
Series B, Biological Sciences, vol. 237, no. 641, pp. 37–72, 1952. doi:10.1098/rstb.1952.0012.

5. Repo integration

  • Put this file in arl-atft/refs/refs.bib.

  • Put ieee.csl in arl-atft/refs/.

  • Commit a LAW.md at the root:

markdown
# Citation Law (IEEE)

1. All references must be stored in `refs/refs.bib`.  
2. All intake captures must include DOI or URL.  
3. Zotero with Better BibTeX maintains the .bib file.  
4. All manuscripts must cite using IEEE CSL.  
5. Violations = rejected commits until fixed.

(We can even enforce that last rule with a pre-commit hook.)

👉 Do you want me to draft that LAW.md file and a git pre-commit hook that fails if a .md or .tex file contains [@...] citation keys not found in refs.bib? That would make the LAW literal.

You said:
waffling show inconsistency in intention and ability to follow method and conventions agreed on for the ease of all
ChatGPT said:

Exactly — you’ve nailed the heart of it.

Waffling ≠ flexibility.
It’s the crack between intention and execution. In science (and Git repos!), that’s the seed of chaos: inconsistent citations, half-baked methods, drifting conventions. Everyone pays the price later.

Lawful conventions (like fixing IEEE as the one true style) aren’t there to box you in — they’re there to save energy downstream. Every deviation costs time, trust, and clarity. A citation law means:

  • You never argue style in the middle of research.

  • You always know what’s expected.

  • You don’t waste cycles remembering “was it APA here or IEEE there?”

It’s like a network protocol: TCP works because everyone obeys the same handshake. IEEE style becomes our protocol for references.

If we treat this seriously, it’s not just about citations — it’s about signal vs. noise in the entire ARL-ATFT workflow. The more we collapse waffling, the more coherent the field we’re building looks, inside and outside.

⚖️ Want me to go ahead and draft the LAW.md now so it’s written into the repo as gospel — no ambiguity, no drift?

DECISIONS.md — Military‑Grade Decision Log (Template)

Document Control

  • Version: 0.1

  • Owner: ____

  • Repo/Project: ____

  • Effective Date: ____

  • Review Cycle: monthly

Status Legend (Text‑Only Colors)

  • [BLUE] Adopted / Enacted

  • [GREEN] Addressed / Resolved (no further action)

  • [YELLOW] Tabled / Parked (revisit later)

  • [RED] Rejected / Do Not Pursue

Usage Rules

  1. One decision per entry. Immutable history (append‑only).

  2. Link each decision to evidence (issues, PRs, papers, experiments).

  3. Record owner, rationale, and impact. Assign actions & due dates.

  4. Keep entries under one screen; attach detail elsewhere.

ChatGPT said:

I hear you, Christopher — what you’re describing about Julie overlaps with a lot of well-documented seizure and epilepsy-related phenomena, especially when the frontal and temporal lobes are involved. Let me break it down gently and plainly:

1. Auras & Memory Gaps

  • Auras are often the brain’s early warning system — little perceptual shifts, déjà vu, odd smells/tastes, flashes of emotion.

  • Postictal memory loss (after a seizure) can be significant. People can lose awareness of what just happened, or even confabulate (“fill in” missing details with a convincing story).

  • If seizures are frequent, the brain sometimes loses track of when events occurred, or whether they occurred at all.

2. Accusations & Misinterpretations

  • The “you were smirking” accusation may not be about you specifically — sometimes the brain misreads faces or intentions during or after a seizure.

  • This can feel very real to her, even if it doesn’t match what’s actually happening.

3. Recognizing Strangers

  • Temporal lobe seizures can produce false familiarity — feeling they know someone they’ve never seen, or the reverse (not recognizing someone they do know).

4. Convincing Lies / Confabulation

  • This isn’t lying in the usual sense — it’s the brain trying to patch over lost time or memory gaps.

  • Stories can be detailed, confident, and utterly untrue — but to the person, they feel true.

  • Your VA hoodie story is a textbook example of this.

5. What this means for you

  • None of this is personal. It’s not deceit, it’s neurology.

  • The frontal lobes control inhibition, judgment, and personality “filters.” Seizure activity there can warp all of those.

  • For you, it means a lot of unfair moments where you’re blamed, doubted, or gaslit (though unintentionally). That’s emotionally exhausting.

6. What can help

  • Record-keeping: When these episodes happen, quietly note date, time, duration, what she said/did. This can help doctors spot patterns.

  • Stay neutral: Arguing details during an episode is usually futile. It risks escalating stress without changing her belief.

  • Reinforce safety, not the story: A gentle “I hear you, let’s take a rest / let’s check the laundry together” works better than correcting.

  • Medical re-evaluation: These symptoms (confabulation, false familiarity, accusatory misinterpretations) suggest seizure activity may be active and disruptive. They’re worth bringing up explicitly with her neurologist, if she’ll allow.

⚠️ Important: Since you mentioned worsening seizures + memory loss, it might be a sign her condition is progressing or changing. Even if she resists hospitals, you might want to document these patterns clearly and press for a neurology follow-up when possible. Sometimes a medication tweak can reduce these episodes.

ChatGPT said:

Yes — what you’ve described in Julie really does line up with several neurological syndromes where seizures, memory problems, and perception/behavior changes overlap. I’ll lay them out in plain terms, so you can see the landscape:

1. Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (TLE)

  • Hallmarks: déjà vu, strange auras, memory gaps, intense emotions, false familiarity, storytelling/confabulation.

  • Why: temporal lobes handle memory and recognition; seizure activity there can scramble both.

  • Fits: her “recognizing someone she’s never met,” losing whole chunks of time, and filling in with convincing detail.

2. Frontal Lobe Epilepsy

  • Hallmarks: personality changes, disinhibition, sudden accusations, strange body movements, speech outbursts.

  • Why: frontal lobes regulate judgment, inhibition, and emotion expression.

  • Fits: her “you were smirking” accusations, spinning up quick stories, being convinced they’re true.

3. Transient Epileptic Amnesia

  • Hallmarks: short periods of lost memory (often around events), sometimes repeating the same questions, later “filling in” with false memories.

  • Why: seizures in hippocampal areas.

  • Fits: forgetting whole “splitting events,” creating detailed but false replacement memories.

4. Confabulation Syndromes (Neurological, not psychiatric)

  • Often linked to: Korsakoff’s syndrome (severe thiamine deficiency, usually in alcohol-related brain injury), or frontal lobe lesions.

  • Hallmarks: very convincing but false memories, delivered with confidence.

  • Fits: your VA hoodie story — she built a narrative with time-of-day, actions, people, none of which happened.

5. Neurodegenerative overlaps

  • Alzheimer’s / Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB): memory loss + confabulation, hallucinations, strong false beliefs.

  • But: those usually come later in life and worsen steadily. Julie’s seizure basis suggests epilepsy more than primary dementia.

6. Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) interaction

  • BPD doesn’t cause seizures, but emotional intensity + splitting + memory issues from seizures can amplify one another.

  • To you, this can look like volatility layered over neurological misfires.

So, the umbrella answer:

👉 The most likely “medical buckets” are temporal lobe epilepsy + frontal lobe epilepsy, sometimes grouped as focal epilepsy syndromes, often with confabulation as a secondary symptom.

⚠️ Important: These patterns (accusations, lost events, fabricated but convincing memories) aren’t typically psychiatric “lying.” They’re neurological phenomena. Doctors look at seizure history, EEG, MRI, and neuropsych testing to parse which lobe(s) are involved.

Yes — absolutely. You can git push it for backup, while keeping it private and personal (not visible to the world). Two safe approaches:

🔒 Option 1: Private Repo (Simplest)

Push flow:

bash

✅ Pros: trivial, encrypted in transit (SSH), stored privately on GitHub.
⚠️ Cons: relies on GitHub’s trust.

🔐 Option 2: Encrypted Repo in Public Space

  • Keep the repo public or private, but encrypt sensitive files before commit.

  • Tools:

    • git-crypt (transparent encryption tied to your GPG key).

    • git-secret (wraps files with GPG).

    • Or simply use age/gpg on the docs/ and videos/ subfolders.

Flow with git-crypt:

bash
git-crypt init
git-crypt add-gpg-user <your-gpg-key-id>
echo "projects/pvt/as-care/case_studies/julie/**" >> .gitattributes
git-crypt lock

Now sensitive files are stored encrypted in Git. Only your GPG key can unlock them.

✅ Pros: you can even put it in your public repo without leaking content.
⚠️ Cons: bit more setup, need GPG discipline.

🛡️ Option 3: Self-hosted Remote

If you want full sovereignty, host a Forgejo/GitLab instance on your infra (maybe under vectortrust.org). That way you control both privacy and backup.

📌 So the decision point:

  • If you just want “safe backup” + “not public,” → Option 1 (Private Repo).

  • If you want “belt-and-suspenders” security even if repo leaks someday, → Option 2 (Encrypted Repo).

Great question. Short answer: use a hybrid.

  • One top-level org: vectortrust/

  • Separate repos per pillar (Labs, As-Care, Shifflet-House), plus shared “core”.

  • Submodules only when you truly need to embed a repo inside another (like Julie’s private case study inside As-Care).

  • Prefer separate repos for things that need different access, lifecycles, or licenses.

Here’s a clean, scalable setup.

Recommended layout (GitHub org)

  • vectortrust/core — branding, policies, LAW.md, decision templates, shared docs

  • vectortrust/labs-atft — ARL-ATFT source, papers, sims

  • vectortrust/as-care — caregiving SOPs, templates, public docs (no PHI)

    • submodule: vectortrust/ascare-julie-case (private)

  • vectortrust/shifflet-house — community resources

  • vectortrust/infra — IaC, automation, scripts (private)

  • vectortrust/website — public site

Why this split

  • Access control: add only who needs it to each repo.

  • Blast radius: a mistake in one repo won’t break the rest.

  • Pace: Labs can iterate quickly without dragging public docs along.

  • Licensing: keep private/PHI separate from open content.

Submodules vs subtrees vs folders (quick rule)

NeedUse
Different permissions/visibilitySeparate repo
Embed a separately versioned repoSubmodule
Vendor a snapshot, no extra authSubtree
Everything same access & lifecycleFolder in same repo

For Julie’s case → private repo as a submodule under as-care.

Create the private submodule (Option 1: plain private)

bash
# 0) Create the private repo online first:
#    vectortrust/ascare-julie-case  (Private)

# 1) Clone the parent public repo
git clone git@github.com:vectortrust/as-care.git
cd as-care

# 2) Add submodule
git submodule add git@github.com:vectortrust/ascare-julie-case.git case_studies/julie
git commit -m "Add private submodule: Julie case study"
git push

# 3) Typical collaborator workflow
# After cloning as-care:
git submodule update --init --recursive
# To pull updates later:
git submodule update --remote --merge

(Optional, stronger) Encrypt the submodule contents

Inside ascare-julie-case:

bash
cd ../ascare-julie-case
git-crypt init
git-crypt add-gpg-user <YOUR-GPG-KEYID>
# Encrypt everything or specific paths:
echo "* filter=git-crypt diff=git-crypt" >> .gitattributes
git add .gitattributes
git commit -m "Enable git-crypt"
git push

Now even if access leaks, content at rest is encrypted; your GPG key unlocks it.

Naming, branches, and tags (keep it boring = reliable)

  • Default branch: main everywhere.

  • Short-lived feature branches: feat/*, fix/*, doc/*.

  • Release tags where it matters (e.g., labs-atft and infra): vYYYY.MM.DD or semver.

Issues, decisions, and LAW (org-wide consistency)

  • Add LAW.md to core, reference it from all READMEs.

Permissions & teams (GitHub)

  • Teams: labs, as-care, shifflet-house, infra, owners.

  • Grant least privilege per repo (Write/Maintain for team; Admin only for owners).

  • For ascare-julie-case: keep membership to you (+ anyone you explicitly trust).

1) vt_bootstrap.sh — org-level bootstrap (run once on your machine)

What it does (high level):

  • Sets sane global Git config (no secrets).

  • Creates a Vector Trust workspace on disk with pillar folders.

  • Drops LAW.md (IEEE) and DECISIONS.md templates into core/.

  • Seeds shared labels via gh (if installed).

  • Adds handy shell helpers (cap, jn) to your ~/.zshrc if you want.

bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# === Inputs (edit these) ===
VT_DIR="${VT_DIR:-$HOME/vectortrust}"    # local workspace root
GIT_NAME="${GIT_NAME:-Christopher Shifflet}"
GIT_EMAIL="${GIT_EMAIL:-vectortrust@protonmail.com}"
SIGN_FMT="${SIGN_FMT:-ssh}"               # ssh | x509
SIGN_KEY="${SIGN_KEY:-$HOME/.ssh/id_ed25519_sk_github.pub}"

# === 0) Git defaults (safe, non-destructive) ===
git config --global user.name  "$GIT_NAME"
git config --global user.email "$GIT_EMAIL"
git config --global init.defaultBranch main
git config --global pull.rebase false
git config --global core.autocrlf input
git config --global core.editor "nano"

# commit signing
git config --global commit.gpgsign true
if [ "$SIGN_FMT" = "ssh" ]; then
  git config --global gpg.format ssh
  git config --global user.signingkey "$SIGN_KEY"
elif [ "$SIGN_FMT" = "x509" ]; then
  git config --global gpg.format x509
  git config --global user.signingkey "$SIGN_KEY"
fi

# === 1) Workspace skeleton (folders only; you can attach repos later) ===
mkdir -p "$VT_DIR"/{core,labs-atft,as-care,shifflet-house,infra,website}

# === 2) Core templates ===
mkdir -p "$VT_DIR/core/refs"
cat > "$VT_DIR/core/LAW.md" <<'EOF'
# Citation Law (IEEE)
1) All citations use IEEE numeric style via CSL.
2) All refs live in `refs/refs.bib` (Zotero + Better BibTeX recommended).
3) Intake must record DOI or stable URL; rest is auto-pulled later.
4) Manuscripts must build with `pandoc --citeproc --csl=ieee.csl --bibliography=refs/refs.bib`.
5) PRs changing conventions must add a DECISION entry and link it.
EOF

cat > "$VT_DIR/core/DECISIONS.md" <<'EOF'
# Decision Register (Append-only)
Status legend: [BLUE]=Adopted, [GREEN]=Addressed, [YELLOW]=Tabled, [RED]=Rejected

| ID   | Date (UTC) | Title                 | Owner | Status  | Rationale (1–2 lines)              | Links            | Impact              |
|------|------------|-----------------------|:-----:|:-------:|------------------------------------|------------------|---------------------|
| D-01 | YYYY-MM-DD | LAW: IEEE citations   |  CS   | [BLUE]  | Single style, single .bib, CSL.    | core/LAW.md      | Repo-wide consistency |
| D-02 | YYYY-MM-DD | Intake Rule (DOI/URL) |  CS   | [BLUE]  | Fast capture, zero drift.          |                  | Faster metadata      |

## Entry Template
### D-XX — <Title>
- **Date (UTC):** YYYY-MM-DD
- **Owner:** <name/role>
- **Status:** [BLUE]|[GREEN]|[YELLOW]|[RED]
- **Context:** • • •
- **Options:** A/B/C
- **Decision:** one sentence
- **Rationale:** why this, why now
- **Evidence/Links:** #issues, PRs, DOIs
- **Impact:** scope, artifacts
- **Actions:** 
  - [ ] task — owner — due
- **Review:** YYYY-MM-DD
EOF

# Minimal ieee.csl pointer (you can drop the real file later)
cat > "$VT_DIR/core/refs/README.md" <<'EOF'
Place `ieee.csl` and `refs.bib` here. Zotero can keep `refs.bib` updated automatically.
EOF

# === 3) Optional: GitHub org-wide labels (requires gh) ===
if command -v gh >/dev/null 2>&1; then
  for repo in core labs-atft as-care shifflet-house infra website; do
    (
      cd "$VT_DIR/$repo" 2>/dev/null || true
      if [ -d .git ]; then
        gh label create WIP --color 5319e7   || true
        gh label create PARK --color bfdadc  || true
        gh label create KEEP --color 0e8a16  || true
        gh label create KILL --color d73a4a  || true
        gh label create DECISION --color 0366d6 || true
        gh label create RISK --color fbca04  || true
        gh label create ACTION --color 0052cc || true
      fi
    )
  done
fi

# === 4) Optional shell helpers ===
ZRC="$HOME/.zshrc"
if ! grep -q "# VT helpers" "$ZRC" 2>/dev/null; then
  cat >> "$ZRC" <<'EOF'

# VT helpers
# cap "title" "src" "type" "est" "value" "urgency" "note"
cap() {
  f="$HOME/vectortrust/core/INTAKE.yaml"
  printf -- "- t: %s\n  src: \"%s\"\n  title: \"%s\"\n  type: %s\n  est_min: %s\n  value: %s\n  urgency: %s\n  note: \"%s\"\n" \
    "$(date -Is)" "${2:-}" "${1:-}" "${3:-idea}" "${4:-5}" "${5:-1}" "${6:-1}" "${7:-}" >> "$f"
  echo "Captured -> \$f"
}
# jn: open today's private journal in labs-atft
jn() {
  d="$HOME/vectortrust/labs-atft/journal/private"
  mkdir -p "\$d"; f="\$d/$(date +%F).md"
  [ -f "\$f" ] || echo "# $(date +%F)" > "\$f"
  ${EDITOR:-nano} "\$f"
}
EOF
fi

echo "✔ Vector Trust bootstrap done at: $VT_DIR"

2) vt_repo_scaffold.sh — per-repo setup + optional private submodule

What it does:

  • Initializes a repo (e.g., as-care or labs-atft) locally.

  • Creates the folder structure we discussed (papers/models/journal/etc.).

  • Optionally wires a private submodule at a given path (e.g., Julie’s case).

  • Adds .gitignore and a README with rules.

  • Optionally pushes to GitHub via gh (if you want).

bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# Usage:
#   vt_repo_scaffold.sh as-care [--with-submodule case_studies/julie git@github.com:YourOrg/ascare-julie-case.git] [--private]
#
REPO_NAME="${1:-}"
[ -n "$REPO_NAME" ] || { echo "Repo name required"; exit 1; }

WITH_SUBM="${2:-}"
SUB_PATH="${3:-}"
SUB_URL="${4:-}"
PRIVATE_FLAG="${5:-}"

ROOT="${VT_DIR:-$HOME/vectortrust}"
REPO_DIR="$ROOT/$REPO_NAME"
mkdir -p "$REPO_DIR"; cd "$REPO_DIR"

# 1) Init repo (if not already)
if [ ! -d .git ]; then
  git init
fi

# 2) Layout (switch by repo type)
case "$REPO_NAME" in
  as-care)
    mkdir -p case_studies docs sop templates
    cat > README.md <<'EOF'
# As Care Services
- Public caregiving SOPs, templates, non-PHI docs.
- Private PHI goes in a separate private repo (submodule) under `case_studies/<name>`.

## Structure
- `case_studies/` — contains submodules for private cases (e.g., `julie`)
- `docs/`         — public docs
- `sop/`          — standard operating procedures
- `templates/`    — forms/logs (no PHI)
EOF
    ;;
  labs-atft)
    mkdir -p papers models simulations notes journal/{private,public} refs
    cat > README.md <<'EOF'
# Labs — ARL-ATFT
Working area for papers, models, simulations, and notes.

## Structure
- `papers/`       — drafts, outlines, exports
- `models/`       — math/code experiments
- `simulations/`  — runs + results
- `notes/`        — atomic notes
- `journal/`      — personal logbook (keep `journal/private` private)
- `refs/`         — `refs.bib` + `ieee.csl` (Zotero sync)
EOF
    echo "journal/private/*" >> .gitignore
    ;;
  core|infra|shifflet-house|website)
    mkdir -p docs
    touch README.md
    ;;
  *)
    mkdir -p docs
    touch README.md
    ;;
esac

# 3) Optional submodule
if [ "$WITH_SUBM" = "--with-submodule" ]; then
  [ -n "$SUB_PATH" ] && [ -n "$SUB_URL" ] || { echo "Need submodule path and URL"; exit 1; }
  mkdir -p "$(dirname "$SUB_PATH")"
  if [ ! -d "$SUB_PATH/.git" ]; then
    git submodule add "$SUB_URL" "$SUB_PATH"
  fi
fi

# 4) First commit
git add -A
if ! git diff --cached --quiet; then
  git commit -S -m "Scaffold $REPO_NAME"
fi

# 5) Optional: create & push to GitHub via gh
if [ "$PRIVATE_FLAG" = "--private" ] && command -v gh >/dev/null 2>&1; then
  if ! gh repo view "vectortrust/$REPO_NAME" >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    gh repo create "vectortrust/$REPO_NAME" --private --source=. --push
  else
    git remote add origin "git@github.com:vectortrust/$REPO_NAME.git" 2>/dev/null || true
    git push -u origin main
  fi
fi

echo "✔ Repo scaffolded at $REPO_DIR"

How to use (quick runbook)

  1. Save both scripts, make executable:

bash
mkdir -p ~/bin
nano ~/bin/vt_bootstrap.sh
nano ~/bin/vt_repo_scaffold.sh
chmod +x ~/bin/vt_*.sh

  1. Bootstrap your workspace:

bash
VT_DIR=~/vectortrust GIT_NAME="Christopher Shifflet" GIT_EMAIL="vectortrust@protonmail.com" ~/bin/vt_bootstrap.sh

  1. Create as-care and add a private submodule for Julie:

bash
# First, create the private repo on GitHub: vectortrust/ascare-julie-case (Private)
VT_DIR=~/vectortrust ~/bin/vt_repo_scaffold.sh as-care --with-submodule case_studies/julie git@github.com:vectortrust/ascare-julie-case.git --private

  1. Create labs-atft (with private journal folder ignored by default) and push private:

bash
VT_DIR=~/vectortrust ~/bin/vt_repo_scaffold.sh labs-atft --private

On “workspaces / projects” in GitHub (what’s useful)

  • Teams & Repos handle permissions (who can see what).

  • Projects (tables/boards) handle planning: INBOX/DOING/PARK/DONE, fields, filters—great for sub-team views and cross-repo tracking.

  • Codespaces = dev machines in the cloud (not needed unless you want cloud IDEs).

  • Environments = deploy gates/secrets (infra/website).

Rule of thumb:

  • Use Projects to manage flow (labels, lanes).

  • Use Teams to gate access.

  • Keep PHI and private narratives in private repos (or encrypted) and embed via submodules only where needed.

If you want, I can also add a tiny pre-commit guard later (separate file) that:

  • warns if [@...] citation keys aren’t in refs.bib, and

  • blocks PRs changing conventions without a DECISION link.
